item.title: Jack Teixeira: The Airman Who Wanted to Give Gamers a Real Taste of War
item.description: A group liked online war games. But then Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old National Guard airman, began showing members classified documents, they say.
item.dc:creator: Aric Toler, Christiaan Triebert, Haley Willis, Malachy Browne, Michael Schwirtz and Riley Mellen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Macron’s Plan to Increase the Retirement Age Clears Key Legal Test
item.description: A constitutional council reviewing President Emmanuel Macron’s law upheld an increase in the retirement age, but struck down some sections. Anger over the plan remains high.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A rally outside City Hall in Paris on Friday to protest the pension overhaul. Few expect the Constitutional Council’s decision to put an end to the intense political and social turmoil that the government’s plan kindled.

item.title: Biden Overcome After Seeing Priest Who Gave Last Rites to Son Beau
item.description: President Biden was in tears after the surprise meeting with the priest, Friar Frank O’Grady, who was given a last-minute security approval to meet with the president.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Biden touring the basilica at the Knock Shrine in County Mayo, Ireland, on Friday.

item.title: After Shunning Assad for Years, the Arab World Is Returning Him to the Fold
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria was isolated for years after brutally crushing his country’s Arab Spring uprising. But in most Arab capitals today, the only question is how — not whether — they should deal with him again.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim, Raja Abdulrahim and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: United Arab Emirates Presidential Court /EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A photograph released by the United Arab Emirates presidential court showing President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, left, and the Emirati ruler, Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed, in Abu Dhabi, the United Arab Emirates, last month.

item.title: Decades on From Peace, Northern Ireland Schools Are Still Deeply Divided
item.description: The nation’s school system still sees the country’s pupils starkly divided by their religious backgrounds, years after the Good Friday Agreement brought an end to sectarian strife.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Andrew Testa
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Practicing the Stations of the Cross at the Catholic St Joseph’s Primary School in the Falls Road neighborhood of West Belfast.

item.title: Jung Chae-yull, South Korean Actress, Is Found Dead at 26
item.description: Though the cause of the unexpected death of Jung Chae-yull was not disclosed, it has renewed concerns about mental health in the country’s highly competitive entertainment industry.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young

item.title: The Great Goat War of Southern France
item.description: A former Parisian moved to the country, fell in love with goats and let them roam free and multiply. Her winemaking neighbors are not enchanted.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ms. Corbeaux’s goats in Saint-André-de-Roquelongue. The male goats, whose horns are marked with purple, have recently been castrated.

item.title: Document Says Ukrainian Agent Attacked Plane in Belarus Against Orders
item.description: A leaked U.S. intelligence document says Ukraine’s president called off a planned attack on a Russian surveillance plane in Belarus, but a rogue Ukrainian agent carried it out anyway. Here is what we’re covering:
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident talking to a Ukrainian soldier in Chasiv Yar, in eastern Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: How Much Power Should the Courts Have?
item.description: In Israel, the United States and other democracies, bitter battles are being waged over the same question.
item.dc:creator: Emily Bazelon

item.title: Germany Quits Nuclear Power, Ending a Decades-Long Struggle
item.description: The last three plants in Germany are scheduled to shut down by Saturday, while other European countries are looking to expand nuclear energy.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Germany’s move to phase out nuclear energy makes it an outlier in much of the industrialized world.

item.title: What Do the Leaked U.S. Intelligence Documents Say?
item.description: The authorities have so far made one arrest in the case, Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old air national guardsman. But many questions remain about the classified documents that have been appearing online.
item.dc:creator: Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers near a frontline position in eastern Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: North Korea Says It Launched a Solid-Fuel ICBM, a First
item.description: If successfully developed, solid-fuel technology would be a significant advance, making the North’s missiles easier to move and harder to target.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: KCNA via KNS, via Associated Press
item.media:description: State media on Friday released this photo of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, center, his daughter and an unidentified person, said to be watching the launch of the North’s new missile on Thursday.

item.title: El Chapo’s Sons Face Sweeping New Charges in Fentanyl Indictments
item.description: The charges, in five related cases, offered a panoramic view of how the deadly drug was created, transported and ultimately sold by the Sinaloa cartel on American streets.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser and Alan Feuer
item.media:description: “The Justice Department is attacking every aspect of the cartel’s operations,” Attorney General Merrick B. Garland said at a news conference in Washington on Friday.

item.title: Pressure Mounts on China to Offer Debt Relief to Poor Countries Facing Default
item.description: There was optimism at the spring meetings of the I.M.F. and World Bank that China will make concessions over restructuring its loans.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: China has lent more than $500 billion to developing countries through its lending program, making it one of the world’s largest creditors.

item.title: Billy Waugh, 93, ‘Godfather of the Green Berets,’ Is Dead
item.description: He was a Special Forces soldier during the Vietnam War then worked for the C.I.A., tracking Osama bin Laden in Sudan and fighting in Afghanistan after 9/11.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)

item.title: Russia’s Ambassador Says U.S. Threatened Retaliation Unless Evan Gershkovich Is Released
item.description: American officials and The Wall Street Journal have vehemently denied the accusation that Evan Gershkovich was engaged in any kind of spying activity.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Evan Gershkovich, the detained journalist, outside the World Bank headquarters in Washington on Wednesday.

item.title: Will Abortion Kill the Filibuster?
item.description: Courts don’t make laws. Congress does.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: U.S. Capitol.

item.title: Ghosts Past and Present Cross Paths as War Comes to Nuclear Wasteland
item.description: Not everyone evacuated when the Chernobyl nuclear plant melted down in 1986. The few who stayed lived through another calamity when Russian troops marched in.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Emile Ducke
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: This is how Ukraine has survived the war on its power grid.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian electrical workers inspecting a power line in Kyiv replaced after a Russian strike at the end of last year.

item.title: Learning to Love My Incomprehensible Kiwi Accent
item.description: It’s surprising how hard it is for New Zealanders to make themselves understood in America.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:credit: Jonah Rosenberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: In New York — and in many other places — New Zealanders are finding it hard to make themselves understood.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: An arrest in the document leak in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Ex-C.I.A. Psychologist Re-enacts Interrogations for Guantánamo Court
item.description: Lawyers for a Saudi prisoner had the psychologist show some of his practices in an effort to exclude evidence as derived from torture.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Lawyers for Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri have portrayed him as deeply damaged by physical, psychological and sexual abuse in his nearly four years of C.I.A. detention.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: An Arrest in the Documents Leak
item.description: Also, the WTA will return to China.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: The disclosures have rattled the Pentagon, and the diplomatic community.

item.title: Iran and Nicaragua Discussed Military Cooperation, Leaked Report Says
item.description: The two countries had found common ground in opposing “perceived U.S. efforts to expand influence in Latin America,” according to an intelligence update based on C.I.A. intercepts.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: The Iranian foreign minister, Hossein Amir Abdollahian, left, greeting his Nicaraguan counterpart, Denis Moncada, in Tehran in December. Their two countries share grudges against the United States.

item.title: Biden Thanks Ireland for Backing Ukraine
item.description: “I’m at home,” the president told the Irish Parliament to thunderous applause. “I only wish I could stay longer.”
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Biden became the fourth American president to address the Irish Parliament, giving an emotional address that mixed personal themes with the diplomatic.

item.title: Biden Plans an Electric Vehicle Revolution. Now, the Hard Part.
item.description: The administration’s push to supercharge E.V. sales must now surmount resistance from manufacturers and consumers as well as likely legal challenges.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport and Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: If the new electric vehicle rule is enacted as proposed, it could cut the equivalent of two years’ worth of carbon dioxide emissions from the entire U.S. economy.

item.title: As World Warms, Droughts Come On Faster, Study Finds
item.description: When rains fail unexpectedly, higher temperatures can more rapidly parch the ground, to devastating effect.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: The dried bed of the Belan River in India last spring.

item.title: Northern Ireland Shows How Hard It Is to End a Conflict
item.description: Northern Ireland had tremendous economic, political, and geographic advantages — but ending the Troubles still proved extremely difficult.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view over the city of Belfast in March.

item.title: Once Shocking, U.S. Spying on Its Allies Draws a Global Shrug
item.description: Compared with revelations in 2013 of mass surveillance by the National Security Agency, intelligence reports in a trove of recently leaked documents have resulted in limited outrage abroad.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: The classified documents leaked by Edward Snowden in 2013 revealed a new age of spying after the Cold War and Sept. 11, 2001.

item.title: F.B.I. Arrests Jack Teixeira, a National Guardsman, in Leaked Documents Case
item.description: Authorities say Jack Teixeira, a 21-year-old member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard, posted sensitive materials in an online chat group.
item.dc:creator: Haley Willis, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Aric Toler, Christiaan Triebert, Julian E. Barnes and Malachy Browne
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Law enforcement personnel outside the home of Airman First Class Jack Teixeira’s mother in North Dighton, Mass., on Thursday. The F.B.I. had been zeroing in on him for several days.

item.title: The U.S. investigation into the leaked Pentagon documents is ‘getting close’ to finding answers, Biden says.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden commented on leaked American intelligence documents while on a trip to Ireland.

item.title: Seeking Visibility, Pope’s Commission on Sex Abuse Gets a New Home
item.description: In moving from cramped offices to a palazzo, the organization is aiming for more visibility, and to be better able to welcome victims.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Stephanie Gengotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Stefano Simone Mattei and Rev. Andrew Small, both members of the Pontifical Commission for the Protection of Minors, outside of Palazzo Maffei Marescotti in Rome.

item.title: 2 Arrested in Hong Kong After Dousing Police With Water Guns
item.description: Songkran, a traditional Thai festival, often involves splashing and squirting. But the continuing crackdowns on all forms of dissent in Hong Kong made things different this year.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: Revelers splashing water on police officers, among others, during a celebration of the Songkran festival in Hong Kong on Sunday.

item.title: Protests Persist in France as Macron’s Pension Law Nears Last Hurdle
item.description: A constitutional ruling expected on Friday may be the final legal obstacle for President Emmanuel Macron’s push to increase the retirement age. But the plan hasn’t become any more popular.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A demonstration on Thursday in Toulouse, France.

item.title: Belarus Extradites Russian Man Convicted After His Daughter Drew Antiwar Picture, State Media Reports
item.description: Aleksei Moskalyov, a single father, escaped house arrest in Russia after he was charged with “discrediting” the Russian Army over the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Aleksei Moskalyov in a Russian courtroom in March. His case has attracted international attention, in part because it has thrown custody of his daughter into question.

item.title: That Famous Black Hole Just Got Even Darker
item.description: Astronomers recently used artificial intelligence to fine-tune the first-ever image of a black hole, captured in 2019 by the Event Horizon Telescope.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye

item.title: Inflation Keeps Cooling
item.description: Prices aren’t climbing as quickly as they once were.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: As the economy has recovered from the Covid shock and people have started to go out again, consumer demand is shifting to services.

item.title: People who wouldn’t be allowed anywhere near the battlefield in a U.S.-led war are active on the Ukrainian front.
item.description: People who would not be allowed anywhere near the battlefield in a U.S.-led war are active on the Ukrainian front, with ready access to American weapons.
item.dc:creator: Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers trained Ukrainian soldiers last year as part of the Mozart Group, which two former Marines established to help Ukraine.

item.title: Jailed Russian Opposition Leader Aleksei Navalny Is Suffering From Acute Stomach Pain
item.description: Prison staff were forced to call an ambulance for Aleksei A. Navalny, the jailed Russian opposition leader, last week, his spokeswoman said.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny at a court hearing in Moscow in 2021. “We understand that the situation must have been critical,” his spokeswoman said of the episode last week.

item.title: How Putin Became a Hero on African TV
item.description: Pro-Russian content presenting a distorted version of the war in Ukraine and promoting Russia’s interests in Africa is gaining an audience on the continent.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Adam Satariano and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Protesters waving Russian flags and holding a portrait of Vladimir V. Putin gathered in front of the French Embassy in the Democratic Republic of Congo last month.

item.title: How Janelle Jones’s Story About Black Women and the Economy Caught On
item.description: The first Black woman to serve as chief economist at the Labor Department advanced the idea that lifting up people on the margins helps everyone else, too.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.media:credit: Lexey Swall for The New York Times
item.media:description: Janelle Jones, chief economist and policy director for the Service Employees International Union, says helping Black women is the best way to construct an economy that functions better for everyone.

item.title: Inside Bakhmut: Pushed into a corner, the Ukrainian military is determined to hold out.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer

item.title: Lonely Cry for Action as China Locks Up Japanese Citizens on Spy Charges
item.description: Hideji Suzuki says Japan failed him during his six years in a Chinese prison. China’s recent arrest of a Japanese citizen is again testing Tokyo’s resolve.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hideji Suzuki, a Japanese citizen who was released from a Chinese prison after serving a six-year sentence on spying charges, at a cafe in Tokyo last month.

item.title: Ukraine presses allies for more aid before an expected spring counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Wednesday. He was among a group of bipartisan senators visiting.

item.title: Poland’s prime minister says Ukraine needs South Korean artillery shells.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Entous
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki of Poland in Washington on Tuesday. He said that it was critical to support Ukraine’s war efforts.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The battle for Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier back from a frontline position in southern Bakhmut.

item.title: New Leaked Documents Show Broad Infighting Among Russian Officials
item.description: The additional documents also suggest the breach of American intelligence agencies could contain far more material than previously believed.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Aric Toler, Julian E. Barnes, Christiaan Triebert and Malachy Browne
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The body of a Russia soldier recovered by Black Tulip, a Ukrainian humanitarian group. Leaked documents show a rift between Russian officials over the scale of casualties in Ukraine.

item.title: Miscommunication Nearly Led to Russian Jet Shooting Down British Spy Plane, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: Recently leaked intelligence documents called the incident, last year, a near shoot down. Officials said it was more serious than originally reported.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Britain’s defense secretary, Ben Wallace, in London last month.

item.title: Macron Says France Backs Status Quo on Taiwan
item.description: An earlier suggestion by the French president that the security of Taiwan was not Europe’s immediate concern had drawn sharp criticism from some Western allies and commentators.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking during his visit to China last week.

item.title: ‘I’m Comin’ Home’: Biden Takes a Tour of His Irish Heritage
item.description: With his sister, Valerie Biden Owens, and his son, Hunter Biden, in tow, the president spent the first day of his trip to Ireland steeped in family lore.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden touring Carlingford Castle in County Louth, Ireland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Ukraine’s Fight for Bakhmut
item.description: Also, U.S. proposals to revolutionize the auto industry.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at a frontline position in southern Bakhmut on Friday, watching the horizon where Russian troops are stationed.

item.title: Leaked Document Says Russia’s Ally Serbia Is Sending Arms to Ukraine
item.description: The revelation could create tensions between the Kremlin and the Balkan nation.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on a street in Belgrade, Serbia, last year.

item.title: Biden’s Visit to Ireland, in Pictures
item.description: President Biden’s three-day trip will mix diplomacy and personal genealogy as he meets with Irish leaders and traces his own family roots.
item.dc:creator: Kenny Holston
item.media:description: President Biden arriving at Ireland West Airport Knock in County Mayo, Ireland, on Friday.

item.title: Ukraine Needs South Korean Artillery Shells, Poland’s Prime Minister Says
item.description: Leaders in Seoul need assurances that the United States would offer support in the face of any aggressive response from China or Russia, Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki said.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Entous
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki of Poland said that it was critical to support Ukraine’s war efforts.

item.title: Israel’s President Sees Hope for Judicial Compromise
item.description: Isaac Herzog is leading talks to resolve a crisis provoked by a divisive government plan to overhaul the courts. In an interview with The Times, he said he was optimistic about a breakthrough.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: President Herzog is leading mediation efforts to find a compromise on the judicial overhaul. He said that the negotiations were gaining momentum and that consensus was possible.

item.title: What if A.I. Sentience Is a Question of Degree?
item.description: A conversation with Nick Bostrom, a philosopher at Oxford, who has spent decades preparing for the day artificial intelligence is capable of anything the human brain can do.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nick Bostrom is a philosopher at the Future of Humanity Institute at Oxford University and the author of the book “Superintelligence.”

item.title: After a Video Appears to Show a Beheading, Ukraine Opens War Crimes Investigation
item.description: The U.N. mission monitoring human rights in Ukraine said it was “appalled” by the video, which appeared to record the beheading of a Ukrainian soldier by Russian troops.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: Inside Ukraine’s Bloody Stand for Bakhmut
item.description: Pushed into a shrinking corner of the devastated city, the Ukrainian military is determined to hold out for strategic reasons, even as allies question the cost.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers at a frontline position in southern Bakhmut on Friday, watching the horizon where Russian troops are stationed.

item.title: Prince Harry Will Attend King Charles’s Coronation Without Meghan, Palace Says
item.description: The Duke of Sussex will travel to London for the May 6 ceremony amid an ongoing public rift among members of the royal family.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Harry’s attendance at the coronation of his father, King Charles III, has been a subject of speculation as interviews, documentaries and Harry’s memoir, “Spare,” portrayed a rift in the royal family.

item.title: Uneasy Coexistence on Guam: Military Buildup and an Indigenous Upwelling
item.description: The U.S. military is increasing its presence just as the island’s Chamorro people are trying to strengthen their bonds.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Chamorro students paddling in traditional outrigger canoes at Tumon Bay in Guam.
